bboxes.raw_text:
"Saints and Sinners" a. social
club which is made up of men and
women who have had treatment
mental illness, will meet on
Tuesday, January 7, at the Heard
Museum, % E. Monte Vista Road,
at 7:45 pm.


Mr.. Tom Cane, director of the
Museum will conduct the tour and
give a lecture on the exhibits
and their relationship to Arizona
history.


Further information may be
obtained from the Maricopa Men
tai Health Association.
AM 4-43o4.

The Brotherhood of Sleeping
Car Porters, headed by A. Philip
Randolph, won its battle for an
agreement on lower work hours
and a raise in pay.


Labor Secretary w. Willard
Writ announced the agreement
which stretched back to 1901
and a series of disputes between
the union and the railroad Off
Gals.


The settlement averted a strike
which would put crimp in holi-
day travel that spurts to a high
pace at this time of the year.


Assistant Labor Secretary
James ]. Reynolds said three
principal issues we're involved
the porters' monthly work sched-
ule, job protection and wages.


About 1000 porters employed
with the Pullman Co., New York
Central, Chicago, Rock Island
and Pacific and the 500 Line we're
involved.


Wirtz said the negotiators,
headed by President A. Philip
Randolph of the porters' union
and ]. E. Wolfe of the railroad
committee agreed to reduce the
porters' present 2O5-hour work
month schedule to ia hours,
equivalent to a 4O-hour week, In
stages beginning January l, 1864,
and ending July l, 1865.


The negotiators also agreed
upon terms covering seniority OF
Pullman Co., employees when
railroads take over sleeping car
service.


The wage increases are ret
roactive to February l., 1862,
and May l., 1862, and called for
a total raise of STA cents an
hour increasing the porters'
average hourly wage--excluding
tips--from approximately $500
cents per hour to $2.35 an hour.

MIAMI Robert (Bob) McCurdy
a % yr. old Negro from At
lantic City, N. j., is an appren-
tice jockey at Tropical Park in
Florida. He becomes the first
Negro to ever ride at this famous
Miami sports center. Some sayhe
is the first to ever ride in the
state.


McCurdy, a quiet 100 h., won
the riding championship at Car
den State Park in New Jersey.


One of the early great riders
named Isaac Murphy, a Negro was
the first man to win the Ken
lucky Derby three times.


Murphy booted home Buchanan
in 1884, Riley in 1890 and King
man in 1891. Another Negro rider
named Jim Winfield captured the
Kentucky Derby with His Emil
nence in 1901 and Alan-A-Dale
in 1902.

Mr.. and Mrs. Alvin Hicks, 2426
w. Madison, hosted a dinner
party honoring their parents on
Christmas Day. His parents are
Mr.. and Mrs. Willie James Hicks.
Mrs. Hicks parents are Rev. and
Mrs. C. V. Nelson.


Another guest was Mrs. Lille
Mae Hall.

THE HICKS FAMILY
HOSTS XMAS DINNER

DALLAS, Tex. The educa-
tional gap between Negro and
white students may become the
subject of a study in 1864 as a
direct result of letter written
to the Texas Commission on
Higher Education by the South
west Regional Office of the Ma
tional Association for the Ad-
vancement of Colored People.


Clarence A. Laws, NAACP
regular secretary, this week
made public a letter from Lee
Lockwood of Waco. chairman Of
TCHE, in which Mr.. Lockwood
said he would be happy TO pre-
sent TO the commission the
NAACPs request that the state
group make IAN early serious
examination of the quality of
education now available to Ne
groes and other minority groups,
and to provide single standard
of high education for all citi-
zens as quickly as possible


Mr.. Lockwood letter was In
reply to Mr.. Laws letter OF No
vember 80. When MIR. Laws
letter was made public, his po-
sition was supported editorially
by the Dallas Morning News and
the weekly Post Tribune.

IN MEMORY: Mrs. Texanner
Morgan, who passed on Dec. %,
1862. In loving remembrance
from her children Tommie Moore
Vernon and Connie Morgan, and
Clarence Hughes, grandson.

Mr.. and Mrs. Ben Flint of
indianapolis spent the holidays
with Mr.. and Mrs. Aldridge Keith,
laos E. Monte Vista. Mrs. Flint
is Mrs. Keith sister.

Americans rank 10th In per
capita consumption of milk among
the major dairy nations of the
world. Films are first.

The average American World
War II veteran Is As years old,
married with three children,
earns just under $4,000 year
and lives in a $4,000 house.

Attending wedding reception honoring Mr. and Mrs Charles
H. Henry we're Eua Davis Willie Robertson erean Pride Chris
Davis, Perry and Ernestne Moore.


Others Jennie Boone Jack Davis Mrs Peare
anev H. Rnehart Robertson Nathaniel Webb Bessie
Ealm Mabel Rnehart, Dollie Campbell and Nette Wde
